name: Introduction to African American History: Black Americans and the World
base_name: Introduction to African American History: Black Americans and the World
long_desc: Exploring the history of Black Americans requires a global perspective. Beginning with early modern African civilizations, the transatlantic slave trade, the global age of revolutions, the implementation of transnational regimes of racial segregation, to the growth of transnational movements for civil and human rights, this course surveys the history of Black Americans from a global perspective. It analyzes how Black Americans conceived of their social position in relation to others in the world. It also explores how perspectives from across the world made sense of Black Americans. This course will follow Africandescended people as they theorized, moved, migrated, and traveled throughout the world. From this perspective, students will learn about the diasporic dimensions of Black American identity. Students will also trace the historical circulation of Africandescended people, knowledge, culture, and technologies. Students will analyze the important themes of freedom, movement, and migration from a global perspective. Through this course, students will learn that Black American historical actors have and continue to understand their position not only within the domestic social and political spheres of the United States but also in the global order of states and societies. From their marginalized social position, Black Americans, therefore, have articulated alternative frameworks for understanding the United States, the West, and the world. This is an introductory survey course.

custom_fields.goals: Students will explore the global dimensions and perspectives of African American history, from the early modern period to thepresent day. Students will explore how Black Americans understood, engaged with, and theorized their place within a global community andconversely how perspectives from across the world made sense of Black Americans. Students will explore movement and migration circuits of knowledge and cultural experience diasporic connections andcommunication work and labor relationships, international politics and advocacy and global freedom struggles. At its heart is theshifting historical relationship between Africandescended populations spread across the world and the continent of Africa. Students will explore major topics, themes, actors, and historical moments within a globally framed history of Black Americans,including the impact on the present day structural inequalities and discriminatory attitudes. This course will be of particular interest to students interested in African American, United States, and Global History. Students will explore how Black Americans have articulated alternative frameworks for understanding the United States, theWest, and the world. Students will be introduced to the principles of historical inquiry and interpretation including periodization, primary and secondary source analysis, argumentation, and contextualization. Students will be able to identify historical continuities and changes over time.
custom_fields.key_topics: Key topics include African American History, domestic history, and global history.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Discussion (In class, Weekly Online), Progressive Chronology Worksheet, Three Unit Reflection Papers, Film Review Paper, Cumulative Final Project & Presentation.
custom_fields.relevance:
This course fulfills Dietrich College's "Intercultural and Global Inquiry" general education requirement.

This course offers an introduction to African American history, from a global perspective.
custom_fields.learning_resources: One required text, with everything else provided via Canvas.
